docs.abstract: The album’s fragile pages were laced with arsenic, so the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery put the images online last month. Curators have since identified more than 1,000 of the 1,800 subjects.
docs.snippet: The album’s fragile pages were laced with arsenic, so the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery put the images online last month. Curators have since identified more than 1,000 of the 1,800 subjects.
docs.lead_paragraph: More than two decades ago, the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery acquired a 19th- century album filled with nearly 2,000 silhouette portraits, including those of two former presidents.

headline.main: Digitized Silhouette Portraits Shed Light on 19th Century Life

docs.abstract: Some British residents said they received misleading emails suggesting they had secured free tickets to the concert for the coronation of King Charles III at Windsor Castle.
docs.snippet: Some British residents said they received misleading emails suggesting they had secured free tickets to the concert for the coronation of King Charles III at Windsor Castle.
docs.lead_paragraph: At five minutes past noon on Tuesday, Ticketmaster sent Joe Holmes and many others in Britain an email: “Congratulations, you have been successful in the ballot” for two tickets to King Charles’s coronation concert.

headline.main: Ticketmaster Finds Itself in a Royal Mess Over Coronation Concert

keywords.name: persons
keywords.value: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

docs.abstract: Three others were wounded, and the gunman is still at large, the authorities said, after the attack on Friday night at a residence north of Houston.
docs.snippet: Three others were wounded, and the gunman is still at large, the authorities said, after the attack on Friday night at a residence north of Houston.
docs.lead_paragraph: At least five people were fatally shot, including an 8-year-old child, and three others were wounded late Friday night at a home north of Houston, the authorities said, adding that the gunman remained at large.

headline.main: Gunman Kills Five People in Texas Home, Authorities Say

docs.abstract: Three artists preparing a new production of this classic at the Metropolitan Opera discuss what makes it so difficult yet satisfying.
docs.snippet: Three artists preparing a new production of this classic at the Metropolitan Opera discuss what makes it so difficult yet satisfying.
docs.lead_paragraph: There are operas that are challenging for their sheer technical demands — the density of Berg’s “Lulu” or the heroic immensity of Wagner epics. And then there are those that seem simple but are actually some of the most difficult.

headline.main: The Pains and Privileges of Staging Mozart’s ‘Don Giovanni’
headline.print_headline: The Pains and Privileges of ‘Don Giovanni’

docs.abstract: Transplant recipients, doctors and others react to a guest essay by a dying woman with a donor heart.
docs.snippet: Transplant recipients, doctors and others react to a guest essay by a dying woman with a donor heart.

headline.main: Hard Truths About Organ Transplants: The Often Harrowing Aftermath

docs.abstract: In the wake of bank collapses, some have called for the F.D.I.C. to guarantee all deposits. But there may be a more strategic solution.
docs.snippet: In the wake of bank collapses, some have called for the F.D.I.C. to guarantee all deposits. But there may be a more strategic solution.
docs.lead_paragraph: How do we avoid the next run on a bank?

headline.main: Should uninsured deposits get a warning label?

byline.original: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Lauren Hirsch and Sarah Kessler

docs.abstract: The slow and steady dismantling of New College of Florida.
docs.snippet: The slow and steady dismantling of New College of Florida.
docs.lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — When I first met Matthew Lepinski, the faculty chair of New College of Florida, he was willing to give the right-wingers sent to remake his embattled progressive public school a chance.

headline.main: This Is What the Right-Wing Takeover of a Progressive College Looks Like

docs.abstract: All major companies now have roughly the same politics.
docs.snippet: All major companies now have roughly the same politics.
docs.lead_paragraph: A considerable number of Americans appear to believe that Bud Light, a beer owned since 2008 by the Belgian multinational corporation Anheuser-Busch InBev, stands for a set of values that does not include transgenderism. This became clear this month after the transgender activist Dylan Mulvaney posted on Instagram an informal video advertisement for Bud Light that featured a photo of a promotional tallboy can sporting an image of Ms. Mulvaney’s face.

headline.main: Read This Before Shopping for Your Bud Light Replacement Beer
headline.print_headline: Shopping for ‘Woke-Free’ Beer? Read This. Consider This the Next Time Your Beer Betrays You

docs.abstract: Nobody’s going to make a movie about reporters at home with their cursors.
docs.snippet: Nobody’s going to make a movie about reporters at home with their cursors.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I don’t want this to be one of those pieces that bangs on about how things used to be better, and they’ll never be as good again.

docs.abstract: Institutions may settle for a new type of elitism.
docs.snippet: Institutions may settle for a new type of elitism.
docs.lead_paragraph: The rapid abandonment of the SAT and ACT as requirements for college admissions, to the point where more than 80 percent of four-year colleges didn’t require a standardized test for admission in the coming fall, is a milestone in the history of the modern meritocracy. What remains to be seen is whether it’s a marker on the road to the meritocracy’s demise.

headline.main: Can the Meritocracy Survive Without the SAT?
